messageBody:
Mike,

I agree with Dave, on all of his points, but I also want to point out the difference

Java world gives an excellent explanation of the two in this article:

Test for fun and profit, Part 1
http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/jw-10-1999/jw-10-howto-p2.html

but to give you a short explanation.


Unit and component testing
Unit and component tests seek to test the building blocks of an application, typically in isolation from the application's other units and components. Units are generally the atomic elements of an application (single classes, for instance), while components may be composed of one or more units.


Integration testing
Integration tests assess the integration and communication between the components and systems that compose an application.


so as you can see Unit testing is a preface to Integration testing.
When we test, we execute the functions of an application with the intent of exposing defects. A good test is one that is likely to uncover a flaw that was previously unknown.


"Carlson, Dave" <dave.carlson@...> wrote:
Mike,

This is a great question. I come at the subject from almost the opposite
direction. I have done a lot of unit testing, but very little integration
testing (integration testing was done by a different group). My thoughts
have been that writing unit tests rather than integration tests allow me to
develop faster because I do not need to rely on the entire system being up
and running before I can test my code. Also, I never have to wait for
another team to post their fix before moving on. My tests are local, and
tell me if _my_ code is working as intended.

I agree that unit testing does not remove the need for integration
testing(they test different things). I would argue that having a full suite
of unit tests makes it much more likely the integration tests will pass the
first time as long as the system design was correct. Also, bugs found
during unit testing are usually much quicker to find and squash.


--Dave

>
> I have experience with integration testing but not much with
> unit testing.
> I've been reading up on unit testing (e.g. mock objects, test first
> development). However, I have not found an article that explains the
> advantages of unit testing vs integration testing. My
> perhaps naive hunch
> is that the cost-per-bug-eliminated of unit testing is higher
> than that of
> integration testing. It appears this way because a single
> integration test
> tests a lot more code than a single unit test and takes about the same
> amount of time to construct. Plus it seems to me that a
> whole suite of unit
> tests with 100% code coverage cannot guarantee that even the
> simplest system
> wide behavior is correct (e.g. the web page appears). Am I
> wrong about
> this? Can someone refer me information about this topic. A
> scientific
> study paper with real numbers would be welcome.
>
> Mike Bresnahan
